bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218423]
[%Nr. 1624]
[!Entscheide, ob das Gerund in den folgenden Sätzen/Fragen als **Subjekt, Objekt** oder als **Ergänzung zur Verbform** eingesetzt wird.]
1. Dancing is great fun. - [+Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
2. She hates going out at night. - [-Gerund ist Subject][+Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
3. Cooking is my hobby. - [+Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
4. Smoking is bad for your health. - [+Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
5. Do you enjoy swimming? - [-Gerund ist Subject][+Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
6. Geocaching can be dangerous. - [+Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
7. Doing homework is boring. - [+Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
8. My favourite activity is using my smartphone. - [-Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][+Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
9. Why don't you like writing essays? - [-Gerund ist Subject][+Gerund ist Object][-Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]
10. What he really likes is going by bike. - [-Gerund ist Subject][-Gerund ist Object][+Gerund ist Ergänzung zur Verbform]

bit.instruction: Entscheide, ob das Gerund in den folgenden Sätzen/Fragen als **Subjekt, Objekt** oder als **Ergänzung zur Verbform** eingesetzt wird.

bitmark:
[.interview:bitmark--]
[@id:218424]
[%Nr. 1612]
[!Übertrage die deutschen Sätze ins Englische. Benutze das Gerund.]
===
Ich mag es, Bücher zu lesen.
[@example:I like reading books.]
===
[%1]Schwimmen macht Spaß. [@shortAnswer]
[$Swimming is fun.]
===
[%2] Peter ist am Fußballspielen interessiert. [@shortAnswer]
[$Peter is interested in playing football.]
===
[%3] Ich hasse es, Briefe zu schreiben. [@shortAnswer]
[$I hate writing letters.]
===
[%4] Wir sind daran gewöhnt, abends zu arbeiten. [@shortAnswer]
[$We are used to working in the evening.]
===
[%5] Es hat keinen Zweck ins Kino zu gehen. [@shortAnswer]
[$There is no use going to the cinema.]
===
[%6] Ich freue mich darauf, meinen Onkel anzurufen.  [@shortAnswer]
[$I am looking forward to phoning my uncle.]
===
[%7] Meine Mutter ist damit beschäftigt, das Abendessen vorzubereiten. [@shortAnswer]
[$My mother is busy preparing the evening meal.]
===
[%8] Er ist gut im Sprechen. [@shortAnswer]
[$He is good at speaking.]
===
[%9] Ich habe nichts dagegen, nach Hause zu gehen. [@shortAnswer]
[$I don't mind going home.]
===
[%10] Ich würde das Rauchen aufgeben. [@shortAnswer]
[$I would give up smoking.]
===

bit.instruction: Übertrage die deutschen Sätze ins Englische. Benutze das Gerund.

questions.question: Ich mag es, Bücher zu lesen.
Peter ist am Fußballspielen interessiert.
questions.sampleSolution: Peter is interested in playing football.

questions.question: Ich hasse es, Briefe zu schreiben.
Wir sind daran gewöhnt, abends zu arbeiten.
questions.sampleSolution: We are used to working in the evening.

questions.question: Es hat keinen Zweck ins Kino zu gehen.
questions.sampleSolution: There is no use going to the cinema.

questions.question: Ich freue mich darauf, meinen Onkel anzurufen.
questions.sampleSolution: I am looking forward to phoning my uncle.

questions.question: Meine Mutter ist damit beschäftigt, das Abendessen vorzubereiten.
questions.sampleSolution: My mother is busy preparing the evening meal.

questions.question: Ich habe nichts dagegen, nach Hause zu gehen.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218425]
[%Nr. 1618]
[!Setze die richtigen Präpositionen in die Lücken.]

0. He concentrates [_on][@example] physics.
1. My friend is good [_at] playing volleyball.
2. She complains [_about] bullying.
3. They are afraid [_of] losing the match.
4. She doesn't feel [_like] working on the computer.
5. We are looking forward [_to] going out at the weekend.
6. Laura dreams [_of] living on a small island.
7. Andrew apologized [_for] being late.
8. I don't agree  [_with] hunting.
9. The girls insisted [_on] going out with Kerry.
10. Edward often thinks [_of] climbing trees.

bit.body:
0. He concentrates {0} physics.
1. My friend is good {1} playing volleyball.
2. She complains {2} bullying.
3. They are afraid {3} losing the match.
4. She doesn't feel {4} working on the computer.
5. We are looking forward {5} going out at the weekend.
6. Laura dreams {6} living on a small island.
7. Andrew apologized {7} being late.
8. I don't agree  {8} hunting.
9. The girls insisted {9} going out with Kerry.
10. Edward often thinks {10} climbing trees.
bit.instruction: Setze die richtigen Präpositionen in die Lücken.

bitmark:
[.cloze-and-multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218426]
[%Nr. 1626]
[!Wähle die richtige Präposition aus und setze das Verb in Klammern als Gerund in die jeweilige Lücke ein.]

1. I'm afraid [-about][-for][+of][-on][-to][-up] [_losing][!to lose] my smartphone.
2. She's looking forward [-about][-for][-of][-on][+to][-up] [_seeing][!to see] her brother.
3. He is responsible [-about][+for][-of][-on][-to][-up] [_collecting][!to collect] the money.
4. She is used [-about][-for][-of][-on][+to][-up] [_going][!to go] to bed late.
5. He apologized [-about][+for][-of][-on][-to][-up] [_being][!to be] late.
6. Larry never worries [+about][-for][-of][-on][-to][-up] [_making][!to make] friends.
7. We are tired [-about][-for][+of][-on][-to][-up] [_waiting][!to wait] for the bus.
8. She insisted [-about][-for][-of][+on][-to][-up] [_talking][!to talk] to her lawyer.
9. You should give [-about][-for][-of][-on][-to][+up] [_bullying][!to bully] your sister. 
10. They are thinking [+about][-for][-of][-on][-to][-up] [_moving][!to move] to Italy.

bit.body:
1. I'm afraid {0} {1} my smartphone.
2. She's looking forward {2} {3} her brother.
3. He is responsible {4} {5} the money.
4. She is used {6} {7} to bed late.
5. He apologized {8} {9} late.
6. Larry never worries {10} {11} friends.
7. We are tired {12} {13} for the bus.
8. She insisted {14} {15} to her lawyer.
9. You should give {16} {17} your sister. 
10. They are thinking {18} {19} to Italy.
bit.instruction: Wähle die richtige Präposition aus und setze das Verb in Klammern als Gerund in die jeweilige Lücke ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218427]
[%Nr. 1628]
[!Welche Präposition steht nach dem Wort bzw. der Wortgruppe, so dass dann ein Gerund stehen kann?]

1. dream [_of] __+ Gerund__
2. talk [_of] __+ Gerund__
3. be interested [_in] __+ Gerund__
4. think [_of] __+ Gerund__
5. be good [_at] __+ Gerund__
6. insist [_on] __+ Gerund__
7. complain [_about] __+ Gerund__
8. be proud [_of] __+ Gerund__
9. rely [_on] __+ Gerund__ 
10. worry [_about] __+ Gerund__

2. talk {1} __+ Gerund__
3. be interested {2} __+ Gerund__
4. think {3} __+ Gerund__
5. be good {4} __+ Gerund__
6. insist {5} __+ Gerund__
7. complain {6} __+ Gerund__
8. be proud {7} __+ Gerund__
9. rely {8} __+ Gerund__ 
10. worry {9} __+ Gerund__

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218429]
[%Nr. 1614]
[!Welche Präposition steht nach dem Wort bzw. der Wortgruppe, so dass dann ein Gerund stehen kann?]

0. They go on [_reading][@example] __(read)__ the book. 
1. I can't imagine Peter [_going][!go] by bike.
2. He agreed [_to buy][!buy] a new car.
3. The question is easy  [_to answer][!answer].
4. The man asked me how [_to get][!get] to the airport.
5. I look forward to [_seeing][!see] you at the weekend.
6. Are you thinking of [_visiting][!visit] London?
7. We decided [_to run][!run] through the forest.
8. The teacher expected Sarah [_to study][!study] hard.
9. She doesn't mind [_working][!work] the night shift.
10. I learned [_to ride][!ride] the bike at the age of 5.

bit.body:
0. They go on {0} __(read)__ the book. 
1. I can't imagine Peter {1} by bike.
2. He agreed {2} a new car.
3. The question is easy  {3}.
4. The man asked me how {4} to the airport.
5. I look forward to {5} you at the weekend.
6. Are you thinking of {6} London?
7. We decided {7} through the forest.
8. The teacher expected Sarah {8} hard.
9. She doesn't mind {9} the night shift.
10. I learned {10} the bike at the age of 5.
bit.instruction: Welche Präposition steht nach dem Wort bzw. der Wortgruppe, so dass dann ein Gerund stehen kann?

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218430]
[%Nr. 1520]
[!Setze das Wort in Klammern entweder im Gerund oder im to-Infinitiv ein.]

0. They promised [_to sell][@example] __(sell)__ the old comics.
1. We decided [_to buy][!buy] a new car.
2. They've got some work [_to do][!do].
3. Peter gave up [_smoking][!smoke].
4. He'd like [_to fly][!fly] an aeroplane.
5. I enjoy [_writing][!write] picture postcards.
6. Do you know what [_to do][!do] if there's a fire in the shop?
7. Avoid [_making][!make] silly mistakes.
8. My parents wanted me [_to be][!be] home at 11 o'clock.
9. I dream about [_building][!build] a big house.
10. I'm hoping [_to see][!see] Lisa.

bit.body:
0. They promised {0} __(sell)__ the old comics.
1. We decided {1} a new car.
2. They've got some work {2}.
3. Peter gave up {3}.
4. He'd like {4} an aeroplane.
5. I enjoy {5} picture postcards.
6. Do you know what {6} if there's a fire in the shop?
7. Avoid {7} silly mistakes.
8. My parents wanted me {8} home at 11 o'clock.
9. I dream about {9} a big house.
10. I'm hoping {10} Lisa.
bit.instruction: Setze das Wort in Klammern entweder im Gerund oder im to-Infinitiv ein.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218432]
[%Nr. 1622]
[!Entscheide, ob in den Sätzen das **Gerund** oder eine **Progressive Zeitform** steht.]

1. He likes reading books. [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]
2. He is reading books. [-Gerund][+Progressive Zeitform]
3. Reading books can be great fun. [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]
4. He is interested in reading books. [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]
5. He was reading books. [-Gerund][+Progressive Zeitform]
6. He has been reading books for two hours. [-Gerund][+Progressive Zeitform]
7. Instead of reading books Henry went to bed. [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]
8. Do you like reading books? [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]
9. He had been reading books. [-Gerund][+Progressive Zeitform]
10. His hobby is reading books. [+Gerund][-Progressive Zeitform]

bit.instruction: Entscheide, ob in den Sätzen das **Gerund** oder eine **Progressive Zeitform** steht.

2. continuing [_continue]
3. moves [_move]
4. likes [_like]
5. believing [_believe]
6. cleaning [_clean]
7. presenting [_present]

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[%Nr. 4646]
[!Schreibe die richtige Form in die erscheinende Lücke. Wenn du kein Wort einsetzen möchtest, dann tipp ein 'x'. Viel Spaß.]
||rewritten instruction||

Hello,
My name is Susan. I'm fo[_u]rteen and I li[_v]e in Germany. My hobb[_ie]s are go[_ing] to discos and jogging, sometimes I [_listen to] music [_on] the radio. In [_x] July I go swimming in a [_lake]. I haven't [_got] any brothers or sisters. We take bu[_s]es to sc[_h]ool. I [_attend] year 9 at my school. My birthday is on Friday. I hope I will [_get] a new guitar.
I'm looking forward to get[_ting] a[_n] e-mail from you.

Yours,
Susan

bit.body:
Hello,
My name is Susan. I'm fo{0}rteen and I li{1}e in Germany. My hobb{2}s are go{3} to discos and jogging, sometimes I {4} music {5} the radio. In {6} July I go swimming in a {7}. I haven't {8} any brothers or sisters. We take bu{9}es to sc{10}ool. I {11} year 9 at my school. My birthday is on Friday. I hope I will {12} a new guitar.
I'm looking forward to get{13} a{14} e-mail from you.

Yours,
Susan
bit.instruction: Schreibe die richtige Form in die erscheinende Lücke. Wenn du kein Wort einsetzen möchtest, dann tipp ein 'x'. Viel Spaß.

bitmark:

[%Nr. 3910]
[!Setze die in Klammern stehenden Wörter in der richtigen Form in die Lücken ein. Achte darauf, ob die Sätze bejaht oder verneint sind.]

0. [_Open][@example] your books. __(to open)__
1. [_Go][!to go] upstairs.
2. [_Don't swim][!not/to swim] in this lake.
3. [_Do][!to do] your homework.
4. [_Don't play][!not/to play] football in the yard.
5. [_Brush][!to brush] your teeth.
6. [_Don't talk][!not/to talk] during the lesson.
7. [_Don't feed][!not/to feed] the animals in the zoo.
8. [_Read][!to read] the instructions.
9. [_Don't be][!not/to be] late for school.
10. [_Switch off][!to switch off] your mobiles.

bit.body:
0. {0} your books. __(to open)__
1. {1} upstairs.
2. {2} in this lake.
3. {3} your homework.
4. {4} football in the yard.
5. {5} your teeth.
6. {6} during the lesson.
7. {7} the animals in the zoo.
8. {8} the instructions.
9. {9} late for school.
10. {10} your mobiles.
bit.instruction: Setze die in Klammern stehenden Wörter in der richtigen Form in die Lücken ein. Achte darauf, ob die Sätze bejaht oder verneint sind.

1. I play → [_I played]
2. we visit → [_we visited]
3. they like → [_they liked]
4. she dances → [_she danced]
5. you carry → [_you carried]
6. he stops → [_he stopped]
7. you change → [_you changed]
8. we enjoy → [_we enjoyed]

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[%Nr. 3618]
[!Schreibe die kompletten Wortgruppen noch einmal im Simple Past.]

0. she invents → [_she invented][@example]
1. we wash → we washed
2. I arrive → I arrived
3. they destroy → they destroyed
4. you hurry → you hurried
5. she elects → she elected
6. you marry → you married
7. we plan → we planned
8. he discovers → he discovered
9. they travel → they travelled
10. I prefer → I preferred

bit.body:

1. we wash → we washed
2. I arrive → I arrived
3. they destroy → they destroyed
4. you hurry → you hurried
5. she elects → she elected
6. you marry → you married
7. we plan → we planned
